title: Bonds and Fixed Income Securities
description: Understand the world of bonds and fixed income investments, which provide stability and regular income to portfolios.
introduction: Bonds are debt securities that provide regular income and are generally considered safer than stocks. They're essential for building a balanced investment portfolio.

whatAreBonds.title: What are Bonds?
whatAreBonds.p1: A bond is a loan that an investor makes to a borrower (government, municipality, or corporation). In return, the borrower promises to pay interest and return the principal amount at maturity.
whatAreBonds.structure: Bonds have a face value (principal), coupon rate (interest rate), and maturity date.

governmentBonds.title: Government Bonds
governmentBonds.p1: Issued by national governments (e.g., Indian Government Securities, US Treasury Bonds).
governmentBonds.risk: Generally considered the safest type of bonds.

corporateBonds.title: Corporate Bonds
corporateBonds.p1: Issued by corporations to raise capital.
corporateBonds.risk: Higher risk than government bonds but offer higher yields.

municipalBonds.title: Municipal Bonds
municipalBonds.p1: Issued by local governments or municipalities.

bondCharacteristics.title: Key Bond Characteristics
bondCharacteristics.couponRate: Coupon Rate: The annual interest rate paid by the bond
bondCharacteristics.maturity: Maturity: The date when the bond's principal is repaid
bondCharacteristics.faceValue: Face Value: The amount that will be repaid at maturity
bondCharacteristics.yield: Yield: The actual return on investment, considering current market price

bondPricing.title: How Bond Prices Work
bondPricing.p1: Bond prices move inversely to interest rates:
bondPricing.rule: When interest rates rise, bond prices fall. When interest rates fall, bond prices rise.
bondPricing.reason: This happens because existing bonds with lower rates become less attractive compared to new bonds with higher rates.

risks.title: Bond Risks
risks.interestRate: Interest Rate Risk: Bond prices fall when rates rise
risks.credit: Credit Risk: Risk of default by the issuer
risks.inflation: Inflation Risk: Purchasing power may decrease over time
risks.liquidity: Liquidity Risk: May be difficult to sell quickly

keyTakeaways.title: Key Takeaways
keyTakeaways.takeaway1: Bonds are debt securities that provide regular income and return of principal.
keyTakeaways.takeaway2: Government bonds are safest, corporate bonds offer higher yields but more risk.
keyTakeaways.takeaway3: Bond prices move inversely to interest rates.
keyTakeaways.takeaway4: Bonds provide stability and income to a diversified portfolio.
